question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form "\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct."
Find the matrix $\mathbf{M}$ that triples the second row of a matrix.  In other words,
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.\]If no such matrix $\mathbf{M}$ exists, then enter the zero matrix.
inference:
Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} m_{11} & m_{12} \\ m_{21} & m_{22} \end{pmatrix}$. Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} m_{11} & m_{12} \\ m_{21} & m_{22} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} m_{11} a + m_{12} c & m_{11} b + m_{12} d \\ m_{21} a + m_{22} c & m_{21} b + m_{22} d \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}We want this to equal $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}$. Comparing entries, we get
\begin{align*} m_{11} a + m_{12} c &= a, \\ m_{11} b + m_{12} d &= b, \\ m_{21} a + m_{22} c &= 3c, \\ m_{21} b + m_{22} d &= 3d. \end{align*}From the first two equations, we have $m_{11} = 1$ and $m_{12} = 0$. Then $m_{11} b + m_{12} d = b$, so $1 \cdot b + 0 \cdot d = b$.
From the third equation, $m_{21} a + m_{22} c = 3c$.  We have $m_{21} a = 0$ and $m_{22} c = 3c$, so $m_{22} = 3$.
From the fourth equation, $m_{21} b + m_{22} d = 3d$.  Since $m_{22} = 3$, we get $m_{21} b + 3d = 3d$, so $m_{21} b = 0$.

Thus, $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

We check:
\begin{align*} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \cdot a + 0 \cdot c & 1 \cdot b + 0 \cdot d \\ 0 \cdot a + 3 \cdot c & 0 \cdot b + 3 \cdot d \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Thus, the matrix is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}}
I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} pa + qc & pb + qd \\ ra + sc & rb + sd \end{pmatrix}.\]We want this to be equal to $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.$  We can achieve this by taking $p = 1,$ $q = 0,$ $r = 0,$ and $s = 3,$ so $\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}}.$

Comparing entries, we get
\begin{align*} m_{11} a + m_{12} c &= a, \\ m_{11} b + m_{12} d &= b, \\ m_{21} a + m_{22} c &= 3c, \\ m_{21} b + m_{22} d &= 3d. \end{align*}From the first two equations, we have $m_{11} = 1$ and $m_{12} = 0$. Then $m_{11} b + m_{12} d = b$, so $1 \cdot b + 0 \cdot d = b$.
From the third equation, $m_{21} a + m_{22} c = 3c$.  We have $m_{21} a = 0$ and $m_{22} c = 3c$, so $m_{22} = 3$.
From the fourth equation, $m_{21} b + m_{22} d = 3d$.  Since $m_{22} = 3$, we get $m_{21} b + 3d = 3d$, so $m_{21} b = 0$.

Thus, $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

We check:
\begin{align*} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \cdot a + 0 \cdot c & 1 \cdot b + 0 \cdot d \\ 0 \cdot a + 3 \cdot c & 0 \cdot b + 3 \cdot d \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Thus, the matrix is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}}

ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} pa + qc & pb + qd \\ ra + sc & rb + sd \end{pmatrix}.\]We want this to be equal to $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.$  We can achieve this by taking $p = 1,$ $q = 0,$ $r = 0,$ and $s = 3,$ so $\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
